High Availability On the Road with PaaS

I have been talking to lots of people about Stackato recently. A hot topic of conversion is HA. Here I’ll cover a few of the hot points, in a Q&A format.

HIGH AVAILABILITY

How many nodes do we support

How seamless and flexible is the process to add additional nodes?

Node management is simple, see the kato docs.

Specifically, the kato command is used to attach additional nodes, migrate existing nodes, configure network parameters, move containers, application droplets, or services, and to manage node and cluster lifecycle.

Are the HA parameters/characteristics “tunable”?

The HA characterists are “tuned” by adding more redundancy into the system via additional nodes.

How is it guaranteed that multiple app instances do not run on the same node? Is this configurable?

There is no such guarantee at this time. Pease contact us if this is a requirement.

How automated is the Stackato the HA mechanism?

Fully automatic. Whether you have multiple DEAs, CCs, stagers, etc., Stackato will transparently handle the failure of any without noticeable service interruption.

They could also be trying to identify high availability strategies for the data services. Although I’ve implemented HA Postgres/MySQL clusters to use with Stackato before, it was a manual process to set those up and plug them into Stackato. Advanced DB HA techniques like sharding and shared-nothing type setups are somewhat unsupported in Stackato but can integrated once setup by the customer.

Can DEAs be moved on the fly from one node to another? "kato disable dea" on one node, "kato enable dea" on another, just like any other Stackato component.

Can nodes span multiple datacenters and survive a complete datacenter outage?

This is not supported.

What is the health manager monitoring? Specifically can it monitor at the app layer.

Monitors state of apps. It watches to make sure as many instances of each app are running as needed, and starts up additional instances if any go down. Yes, it operates at the app layer.

I have been asked this question several times before as well, and my response is that it checks the web PID for application health. When the application instance crashes, health manager will notify cc to bring up another instance so there is minimal downtime for application crashes, if at all (if you already have multiple instances for an application).

Do we have reference architecture for HA? Whitepapers? Documented performance characteristics?

Can the db and bus and other services be elastically and automatically scaled?

What is our backup/recovery strategy and story, if any? Whitepaper?

+1 to export/import as backup strategy. I offered that as a response to most people and most are okay with it. Although some want a snapshot capability on a per app basis (backup of an app) and I don’t believe that is available.

With regards to recovery, long ago before Stackato is as scalable as it is today, we have suggested multiple cluster (active/passive cluster) as an option for DR strategy. Very few people buy into this idea as there will be challenges syncing data, and really a waste of resources to have a passive cluster. As such, we have punted this to an infrastructure decision because there are already proven DR solution at the infrastructure layer. This is not to say that we should ignore DR related requests. We probably need a good story for a DR solution. To that, Brent, please let us know your take on this.
